name: Tk-95
colors: 8 with two tones each (normal and bright)
ports: Expansion port, tape-recorder (1200 bauds), RF video out, Joystick, Bus expansion
description:
The goal with the TK95 was to offer a true Spectrum compatible system with a case and keyboard as strong and convenient as a Commodore 64.

The inside of the machine was neverthless quite similar to its predecessor, the TK-90, with some ROM improvements that increased the degree of compatibility and corrected some bugs (ROM No Maskable Interrupt) of the original Sinclair and Timex models.
 
Two BASIC command were added, TRACE and UDG (User Defined Graphics) that allowed the specific Brazilian characters to be printed. As the machine was only dedicated to Brazilian market, all the error messages were in Portuguese language. 

The TK-95 was one of the last machine made by Electronica. It didn't sell well because of the massive appearence and great success of MSX computers in South America.

Thanks to Dimitri Kokken for the picture

More information from Mario Villar (Uruguay):
Not all peripherals marketed for the ZX Spectrum were compatible with this machine, specially the Joystick Interfaces.
Microdigital also made peripherals for the TK line under it's own brand: An optical pen, RS-232 Interface, and modems.
In my country (Uruguay), this machine had great success, leaving it to implement a system information service over modem (like a BBS) specially dedicated to that machines, with a modem and interface built here. Also, there was a High Speed tape drive called "Hilow", developed in Uruguay. It has a Snapshot button (NMI interrupt?) and two speeds. The few units ever made were incredibly reliable, still working today.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LARGER VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Dimitri Kokken</b> for the picture</p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is one of the first adverts showing a one computer dedicated software range. In 1979, the computer manufacturers understood that it was not enough any more to sell hardware and that the success of a computer depended now on the range and quality of the software that came with it.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The simple fact is nobody - nobody in the personal computer industry - offers more software than Ohio Scientific! Right now, as you read this, Ohio Scientific has just about 2 million bytes of software available for our C4P MF computer.</font> <br><br> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> adds:<br><font color="#666666"> I'd like to mention that Aardvark Software in Michigan was one of the better vendors of software for the C4P games.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTER NOTES</strong></font><br><blockquote>This fanzine - one of the first of the microcomputers era - was published by the Altair User Group<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Prior to the 6800 computer, MSI manufactured 8" floppy disc units.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special Christmas offer with 12 games.<br><br> Monochrome version: <b>£199</b><br> Colour version: <b>£299</b><br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is another french advert, not from CBS, but from an independant store "le jeu electronique". <br><br> Only the expansion module #3 was available in France and people had to buy a Colecovision if they wanted to have an Adam !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HHC advertising campain was not really attractive: black & white, lots of small characters texts, small pictures...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1986 price list:<br> Monochrome - Single drive: <b>£399</b> + VAT<br> Monochrome - Dual drive: <b>£499</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Single drive: <b>£549</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Dual drive: <b>£649</b> + VAT<br><br> Optional 10 MB hard disk: <b>£300</b> + VAT   </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You're never so well served than by yourself..." <br><br> "...create your own micro-server on Thomson."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (AUGUST 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Yannick Noah Tennis cartridge. The game is only called "Grand Slam Tennis" on the Emerson Arcadia 2001, but in France was marketed with the most famous french tennis player's name, Yannick Noah.</blockquote>

peripherals: all of the Sinclair and third sources peripherals
